p: Our findings showed that substantial levels of spatial heterogeneity in HIV prevalence exist among adults and young adults throughout all 7 Eastern and Southern African countries analysed in this study. Especially in young adults, micro-epidemics of relatively high prevalence alternated with areas of very low prevalence, clearly illustrating the existence of areas with high levels of transmission. Overall, 15.6% (marginal R 2) of the heterogeneity in HIV prevalence could be explained by an interplay of behavioural, socioeconomic, and environmental factors, including number of sex partners, STIs, GHF (a proxy for economic activity), and urbanization. Maps of interpolated random effect estimates at each sample location showed that environmental predictors were better at specifically predicting HIV prevalence at the high-prevalence areas than sexual behavioural or socioeconomic variables, yet substantial heterogeneity at other high-prevalence areas remains unexplained.
